messages: f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:03): i have a file 's' in /
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:04): i'm not sure because i can't cat it or anything
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:04): it says "Operation not permitted" even as root
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:04): where do sockets usually belong?
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:05): / is not the place to keep things
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:05): find out what's using it with fstat
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:05): shows nothing but the subjects
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:06): think i can remove it?
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:08): i'd be interested in finding out what's using it first
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:08): you know any other ways besides fstat?
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:10): if it was using s, what would it look like on netstat?
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:12): s would be shown under the unix domain sockets header with other information like all the other unix domain sockets
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:15): you know what to pass to find out what program is using s?
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:15): you can grep the fstat output for those addresses associated with s
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:15): i see it as s under Addr tabs
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:16): just can't make any meaning with the hex
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:17): now what can we do with these hex values
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:18): nothing useful comes from grepping the fstat output with the addresses from netstat?
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:23): there's got to be a way to get those addresses with fstat but i forget hehe
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:23): install lsof from ports and it will tell you :)
f053d7691ad53f6188becb509a4bad5b (12:25): lsof should show everything, pretty much right?
22ede8b27951465656458530bf6751ee (12:27): just grep the output of lsof for the number under the Address header in the netstat output
